snippet: Shops owned by Arabs have been looted in the city and some residents have fled, a foretaste of ethnic strife that many fear will roil Mali for years.
abstract: Residents of Timbuktu, Mali, tell of terror they endured for nearly 10 months under harsh Shariah law put in place by Islamic militants, until city was liberated by French and Malian troops; rebels, many linked with Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, destroyed tombs of venerated saints and carried out floggings, amputations and executions during reign; while the Islamist militants have retreated to the desert, however, there are no illusions that they have ceased to be a threat.

byline.contributor: Eric Schmitt contributed reporting from Washington, and Scott Sayare from Paris.

lead_paragraph: Shops owned by Arabs have been looted in the city and some residents have fled, a foretaste of ethnic strife that many fear will roil Mali for years.

headline.seo: Timbuktu Endured Terror Under Harsh Shariah Law
